lcn.p: One of the most insidious misconceptions is that a Jedi is to dress according to a principle of modesty. This view, frankly, has no basis in Jedi philosophy whatsoever. Of course, there can indeed be situations in which a Jedi finds it useful in one way or another to dress modestly - whether it is a Consular finding such garb most useful for diplomacy in a certain situation - or merely that that particular Jedi feels more comfortable when dressed modestly for whatever reasons of that Jedi's personal background. However, on no account is modesty itself a general guiding principle of Jedi attire.

Furthermore, those who do promote modest dress as a matter of principle generally do so with reasoning that is patently incompatible with Jedi philosophy. Such arguments generally assume that through how one person (generally a female) dresses she is responsible for the conduct of another person (generally a male). Such arguments can not be accepted by a Jedi. For one thing, they ask the Jedi who wears the clothes to assume responsibility for someone else's actions -- even though we, as Jedi, know that someone else's actions are not in our locus of control. Furthermore, if the one deemed to be responding to such clothing choices happens to also be a Jedi, such an argument would be sending an inherently un-Jedi message that that person may justify zir actions or lack thereof based on what someone else is wearing.

Therefore - the argument used to defend modest dress as a principle undermines the very foundation of what allows us Jedi to be protected from the Dark Side! If a Jedi does choose to dress modestly, may zie make certain that it is not on the basis of such a vile and destructive rationale!
